Desert Peak II Risk Management Plan

Executive Summary



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



It is Ormat Nevada, Inc.'s (Ormat's) policy to adhere to all applicable federal, state, and local laws. The Desert Peak II facility actively manages all operational permits and safety programs such as Nevada Department of Environmental Protection Air Quality, Chemical Accident Prevention Program, Underground Injection Control as well as OSHA's Process Safety Management. In addition, Ormat is ISO 14000 and 9001 certified and undergoes several audit processes to ensure all facilities are aggressively pursuing the highest quality, safety and environmental standards. Ormat is committed to handling the n-pentane systems in a safe manner to protect the environment. Copies of emergency response, process hazard analyses, Chemical Accident Prevention Program and process safety management plans and all technical drawing (P&IDS) for process equipment are maintained onsite for reference.



Facility Description 

The Desert Peak II Geothermal Power Plant is wholly owned by ORNI 3, LLC. which is a division of Ormat Technologies, Inc., a publicly traded company. Desert Peak II is located in Churchill County. The physical plant is located off the Nightingale exit on Interstate 80 east of Fernley Nevada. The leased acreage covers the defined geothermal resource area and receptive injection zones.



Desert Peak 2 consists of one water cooled OEC rated at approximately 7.7 MW (gross), and one air cooled OEC rated at approximately 14 MW. Geothermal fluid is supplied from production wells to a binary system consisting of two OEC's. Spent geothermal fluid will be injected back into the subsurface reservoir via two injection wells.



Desert Peak II is operated by Ormat's Western Nevada Operations Group. The WNV-Operations Group (WNVOPS) is comprised of management, administration, maintenance, engineering and operations personnel. WNOPS operate the Western Nevada po

wer generation facilities owned or operated by Ormat.



Desert Peak II is a remotely operated facility. Remote operations are conducted out of the Galena 3 control room located in Reno, NV. On site staff will typically consist of one plant operator, two maintenance personnel and two electrical personnel which are shared between the Desert Peak II facility and the Brady facility. Additional operational, maintenance, management and administrative support will be provided to the Desert Peak II facility from the Steamboat Complex located in Reno, NV. The Desert Peak II facility will operate continuously 24 hours a day and 365 days of the year (excluding scheduled maintenance downtime or plant upsets).

 

Regulated Substance Handled



Desert Peak II stores n-pentane (CAS # 109-66-0) as the motive fluid used in the Ormat Energy Converter (OEC) units. In accordance with 29 CFR 1910.119 the use of n-pentane as a process or motive fluid in a quantity greater than 10,000 lbs requires the establishment of a PSMP, CAPP and RMP. The total maximum amount of n-pentane to be stored on site is 260,133 pounds. 

 

Worst Case Scenario: Worst case scenario assessment has been made and potential off-site consequence analysis (OCA) was undertaken. However, in conformance with Office of Emergency Management guidance, the OCA for worst-case and/or alternative release scenario(s) has not been included in this Executive Summary because of security concerns.



Safe Work Practices: Safe work practices have been developed and implemented to provide for the control of hazards during work activities such as lock out/tag-out, confined space entry, opening process equipment or piping, and control over entrance into a facility by maintenance, contractor, laboratory or other support personnel. These safe work practices apply to both employees and contractors.



Maintenance Procedures: A Mechanical Integrity Program (MIP) has been developed for the Desert Peak II facility. The MIP adopted a main

tenance concept for periodic preventative and corrective maintenance of the OEC system. The preventative maintenance tasks include visual inspection, lubrication of rotating parts, system cleaning, replacing liquids and filters, and periodic tests to verify that the system is in proper operating condition. Preventative maintenance tasks and procedures are scheduled to be undertaken over a series of maintenance intervals. The Mechanical Integrity Program will identify system maintenance procedures, frequencies and recommended spare parts. Alarm system maintenance is determined using a combination of regulatory requirements, manufactures recommendations, plant operating experience and best practices. 



Standard Operating Procedures: give detailed safe oprating instructions on Safety Information, Precautions, and Normal Operations, Plant Startup and Shutdown and Emergency Operations. Additionally safet operations of Fire Protection and Gas Detection System, Electrical Distribution System, Pentane System, Brine and Steam System, Evacuation, Transfer, and Storage System, Non-Condensable Gas Removal System, Turbine Controls and Support Systems, Compressed Air System and Cooling Water System.



Training: Initial training for personnel is given before that employee is allowed to either handle n-pentane, operate or work on the facility's process area or on process equipment.  Training Qualifications for both operation personnel and maintenancve personnel are required and renewed periodically to validate knowledge and understanding of expected work performance. Refresher training of safety programs are conducted on an annual basis, at a minimum, and when review of the chemicals or process(es) reveals a need for additional training. Initial and refresher training, associated with the RMP program, is documented and maintained per the requirements of the Training.

Relief system design: Relief valves are located on the n-pentane storage tank and on the OEC vaporizers and condensers. Each pressure relief valve relieves directly to atmosphere, and some installations have extension pipes installed to direct the relief valve discharge away from critical machinery. Additionally, each pressure relief valve is installed immediately above a rupture disk designed to fail at the relief pressure of its corresponding relief valve. Individual relief valve locations are equipped with "telltale" gauges in between the relief valve and its rupture disk to allow easy identification of leaking or blown rupture disks. 

    

Ventilation System Design: All components of the n-pentane transfer and storage systems and the OEC units are located outdoors and well ventilated.



Safety Systems: Beyond the relief system the Desert Peak II OEC units have extensive fire protection, detection, and alarming systems as well as an administrative control system aimed at fire prevention.



The fire detection systems include gas monitors which continuously monitor the area surrounding the OEC's, and ultraviolet/infrared flame detectors throughout the plant. The facility has a fire water system setup in a continuous loop around the generating units and within reach of the n-pentane storage tank. The fire water systems consist of fire monitors and hydrants. Operators are trained in the proper use of the installed fire protection equipment, and the training information is appropriately documented by the facility operator.



Process Hazard Analysis



A Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) including Hazard and Operability (HAZOP) study, an external events analysis and a preliminary human factors analysis was undertaken in Ju

rking at the Desert Peak II site. Training includes the following items, but is not limited to: (a) Location and sounds of the gas, fire, and evacuation alarms and detectors; (b) Expectations of response to injuries and emergencies by personnel on site, and (c) Evacuation routes and locations. Refresher training for all personnel shall be conducted annually at a minimum.



Safety Training: Some equipment at the Desert Peak II Geothermal Power Plant poses potential fire, explosion, and electrical hazards that could cause serious personal injuries and costly property damage if safety procedures are not followed correctly. Safety training, conducted monthly and required of all employees, identifies the different hazards to be found on the sites.  These subjects include Emergency Action Plan (EAP), motive fluid hazards, fire prevention and hot work, lock out and tag out procedures, hazard communication, confined space, hearing conservation, personal protective equipment, accident, injury and incident reporting. Safety training is supplemented by the use of the Standard Safety Procedures.



n-Pentane system: Deviation from the design limits of operation for the n-pentane transfer system will not normally occur since the individual components are rated beyond the highest achievable values of pressure, temperature, and flow within the system.

 

OEC Units: The OEC units are controlled and monitored by their own dedicated HMI Programmable Logic Controller (PLC). The PLC receives all discrete (logic) and analog signals from the input devices (e.g.  switches and measuring sensors), processes the signals according to pre-loaded Ormat software, and then outputs logic and analog command signals to local and field devices. All parameters needed for proper operation of the OEC units, such as pressure, temperature, voltage, current, power, speed, etc. are measured by the proper measuring instruments.  Deviation from the operating parameters will immediately be detected by the PL

ly 2006. The recommendations of the PHA were integrated into the facility and facility operations. The PHA is updated and revalidated at least every 5 years to ensure the study is consistent for the life of the pentane processes. 



Five-Year Accident History



There have been no accidents associated with pentane and no accidental releases of pentane.



Emergency Action Plan



The Emergency Action Plan (EAP) is intended to identify and coordinate personnel in the event there is an emergency. The EAP procedures apply to all personnel working at the Desert Peak II facility or monitoring the Desert Peak II plant from the Brady Geothermal control room.  The EAP is submitted to the local fire department for review and approval and when changes are made to the plan. The following information was selectively excerpted from the Desert Peak II Emergency Action Plan (EAP).



Pentane Leak or Fire Emergencies: An emergency is identified as any type of fire, explosion, or motive fluid spill (ruptured vessel, process pipe, etc.) within the plant. Under no circumstances is any person to put himself/herself in danger. A General Response and Action Chart has been prepared to provide guidance on the initial response and follow up actions in the event of a pentane gas, smoke or fire detection alarm.



Implementation, Control and Compliance: The Plant Manager has overall responsibility for the development and implementation of the Emergency Action Plan. The Emergency Action Plan shall be reviewed annually to verify regulatory compliance and accuracy with both OSHA Regulations on Emergency Plans 29, CFR 1910.38 and CAPP's Emergency Response Programs, NAC 459.9544. The Emergency Response Program must also be periodically reviewed and updated and employees notified of any changes in conformance with 40 CFR 68.95. The EAP may also be reviewed, as part of any Incident Investigations or when deemed required during Management of Change. Current copies of the Emergency Action Plan is loc

ated in the Desert Peak II Control Building and in the Brady Geothermal Control Room.



Evacuation of Personnel: In the event of an emergency determined to be pentane system related and evacuation is deemed necessary, the control room operator or other designated personnel will sound the plant evacuation alarm.



First Aid: All Ormat personnel have been trained in adult CPR and basic first aid procedures. 



Control Room Operator: Upon notification from the site that an emergency has occurred, the Control Room Operator shall verify an emergency shutdown of the Desert Peak II plant was initiated and emergency response teams have been called.  The Control Room Operator assumes initial communications with site over emergency situations until relieved by either the Plant Manager or Operations Manager.

Emergency Response Personnel: Fire, police, and/or ambulance crews will be called as necessary.  The senior employee on site at the time of the incident will give a report to the person in charge of the emergency teams.  This report will include currently known causes and effects, reports of injured personnel and their locations, etc.  All other employees are instructed to stay clear unless specifically requested to assist in some manner.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety



The plant has been operating safely for many years and Ormat will continue to ensure extensive training is provided to the operators as they are essential to plant safety. In addition, Ormat will continue to evaluate any new mitigation or control technology that may improve safety at the Desert Peak II Power Plant.
